block.p: NEW BID FOR ABN AMRO Royal Bank of Scotland and two other lenders started the biggest takeover battle in banking industry by offering 72.2 billion euros, or $98.5 billion, for the Dutch bank ABN Amro. The offer trumps a bid by Barclays for the bank. [Page C1.]
EUROPE IS IN A BUYING FRENZY The takeover battle for ABN Amro is just the latest sign of Europe's growing deal frenzy. [C12.]

SIEMENS CHIEF TO STEP DOWN The embattled chief executive of Siemens, Klaus Kleinfeld, said that he would step down when his contract expired in September, becoming the latest casualty in a widening corruption scandal that has shaken corporate Germany. ''In times like these,'' Mr. Kleinfeld, above, said, ''the company needs clarity about its leadership. I have therefore decided not to make myself available for an extension of my contract.'' [C1.]

DOW SOARS PAST 13,000 The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 13,000 for the first time and is up 6 percent for the month, its best performance in a single month since December 2003. The rally has defied skeptics who thought stocks were due for a slide. [C1.]

ASIA'S ANSWER TO SWITZERLAND Singapore is trying to carve out a new niche for itself in the global economy -- as a sanctuary for the world's wealthy and their money -- by bolstering banking secrecy laws and offering generous tax incentives. [C1.]

RULES ON TV VIOLENCE The Federal Communications Commission urged lawmakers to consider regulations that would restrict violent programs to late evening, when most children would not be watching. [C1.]

HOUSING ASIDE, HOPEFUL SIGNS New data on durable goods orders has allayed fears that business investment was about to falter, raising expectations that decent economic growth can continue while the pullback in residential real estate runs its course. [C4.]

PROMOTING U.S. MANUFACTURING United States Steel, Alcoa, Goodyear and other manufacturing companies have formed an unusual alliance with the United Steelworkers, aiming to preserve and promote manufacturing in the United States. [C2.]

DELAY FOR EX-COMVERSE CHIEF Lawyers for Jacob Alexander, the former chief executive of Comverse Technologies who faces charges of options fraud and is regarded as a fugitive, won a fresh delay of attempts to extradite him from Namibia to the United States.[C2.]
SERVERS OF THE FUTURE Sun Microsystems and I.B.M. plan to introduce specialized high-end server systems, providing fresh evidence of a new era in computing. [C12.]

APPLE'S QUARTERLY PROFIT UP 88% Apple Inc. surpassed even the most optimistic forecasts for its usually tepid second quarter, delivering an 88 percent increase in profit on strong sales of Macintosh computers and iPod music players. The company said that its profit rose to $770 million, from $410 million in the comparable quarter last year. Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive, called the quarter a ''blowout.'' [C3.]

NOT GOING QUIETLY Fred D. Anderson, the former Apple board member who appeared to be a fall guy in the federal investigation of Apple's options-backdating policies, has instead made a statement that keeps suspicions swirling around the company's chief, Steven P. Jobs. [C3.]

GETTING ON BOARD WITH JOOST Joost, the Internet television service being developed by the founders of Skype, has lined up several blue-chip advertisers as it prepares for its introduction. Advertising. [C13.]

A WANING INFLUENCE IN HOLLYWOOD As Hollywood's most visible female power brokers have left their jobs and been replaced with men, there is a growing sense that ''women's pictures'' are being pushed aside in favor of action-adventure films like ''300.'' [E1.]

UNCOVERING TALENT IN THE MINORS A business professor and a consultant are using baseball's minor leagues as a model for building networks in underserved and overlooked regions of the country for identifying, recruiting and developing entrepreneurs. Small Business. [C13.]

COLGATE-PALMOLIVE, the consumer products company, said that its first-quarter profit rose 50 percent, driven by sales of new products and growth in all geographic regions. (AP)
QUALCOMM POSTED a 22 percent increase in profit in its fiscal second quarter on strong sales of chips for cellphones. (AP)

GENERAL DYNAMICS AND RAYTHEON posted modestly higher first-quarter earnings, beating Wall Street's expectations, but were reluctant to raise their profit outlooks for the full year, citing unusually high uncertainty over future Pentagon financing. (AP)
UNITED PARCEL SERVICE reported lower quarterly profit as a result of a charge related to aging aircraft and expenses for a voluntary layoff program. (REUTERS)

HIGHER BEER PRICES, fewer discounts and another strong showing overseas offset sluggish United States sales for Anheuser-Busch, which reported a 3.7 percent increase in first-quarter earnings. (REUTERS)
CORNING, THE SPECIALTY glass maker, said that quarterly profit rose 27 percent on better-than-expected demand for telecommunications products, sending its shares up more than 7 percent. (REUTERS)
JEFFREY R. IMMELT, the chairman and chief of General Electric, said that he found the lagging performance of the company's shares ''frustrating.'' (REUTERS)
